title: Hays Travel to buy 555 Thomas Cook stores after recruiting 421 staff members

Independent travel agent Hays Travel has said it will buy 555 stores from Thomas Cook after the holiday company collapsed late last month.

Hays has already recruited 421 former Thomas Cook staff and has offered employment to more of the airline's personnel.

The deal will boost the high street presence of Hays, the UK's largest independent travel group.

Thomas Cook had around 600 stores on UK high streets, its demise put more than 9,000 people out of work in the UK.

"This represents an important step in the liquidation process, as we seek to realise the company's assets," said David Chapman, the official receiver of Thomas Cook.

John and Irene Hays, managing director and group chair of Hays Travel, said: "Thomas Cook was a much-loved brand employing talented people. We look forward to working with many of them."

Jim Tucker, a partner at KPMG and joint special manager of Thomas Cook’s retail division, said: “This is an extremely positive outcome, and we are delighted to have secured this agreement.

“It provides re-employment opportunities for a significant number of former Thomas Cook employees and secures the future of retail sites up and down the UK high street.”

(Image: Jonathan Buckmaster)

Hays Travel said it plans to re-open the Thomas Cook stores with “immediate effect where possible and to take on up to 2,500 people”.

More than 100 new jobs will be based at the firm's Sunderland headquarters with the rest in shops across the UK.

And Hays aren't the only people offering jobs to former staff of the collapsed giant.

Virgin Atlantic said it's offering jobs: "To support any Thomas Cook Cabin Crew after the sad announcement that the company has ceased operations."

"This opening is for current Thomas Cook Cabin Crew or Thomas Cook employees with previous flying experience only," the job ad reads.

You can apply online, or send to a friend, here .

Staff at Thomas Cook's biggest rival Tui are also offering a helping hand.

"We are sorry to learn of the Thomas Cook UK news. We really feel for everyone affected by this announcement - customers on holiday, anyone due to travel with them and of course their employees,"the Tui Jobs Facebook page reads.

(Image: Phil Harris/Daily Mirror)

The collapse of the travel giant left thousands of staff at a loss of what to do next - as well as planes on the ground and stores empty.

Hundreds and potentially thousands of Thomas Cook workers found they simply weren't paid for their work in September.

Others were left relying on handouts from friends and families, signing on for Universal Credit or even using food banks.

According to the Government's insolvency service, more than £2.4million has so far been paid to former employees of Thomas Cook.

Overall, the collapse looks set to cost the Government £60 million in payouts to former staff - whether they find new work or not.
description: The independent travel firm has stepped in to rescue shops from lying vacant and staff from unemployment
